section.title: Passive Circuit Elements
section.introduction:
Resistors, capacitors, and inductors are called passive elements of a circuit while EMF source is called the active element. We analyze a dynamical circuit, such as an AC circuit, using Faraday's loop rule.
In this section, we will work out formulas for voltage drop across each element, which carry amplitude and phase informations now. We will use these formulas to write the EMF side of Faraday's law immediately. That would leave only the magnetic flux side of Faraday's law to work out if the circuit is subject to changing external magnetic flux, otherwise, that side will be zero.
Voltage Drop Across a Resitor
Suppose current I passes through a resistor of resistance R. Then, voltage drop across the resistor, denoted as V_R will be given by Ohm's law.
V_R = R I(t).
For an AC current I(t) = I_0\, \cos(\omega t + \phi_I), we will get
V_R(t) = R I_0 \cos(\omega t + \phi_I).
If we write V_R(t) in terms of its own magnitude and phase constant, i.e.,
V_R(t) =V_{R0} \cos(\omega t + \phi_V),
then, we find that current through a resistor and voltage across resistor are in-phase, i.e., their phases are same.
\phi_V = \phi_I,\ \ \ V_{R0} = R I_0 .
Important thing to note here is that voltage and current amplitudes across a resistor here have same relation as in the DC circuit case and they are in sync with each other.
(Calculus) Voltage Drop Across an Inductor
Suppose current I passes through an inductor of self-inductance L. When current is increasing, then there is a back emf, which can be interpreted as a voltage drop across the inductor and when current is decreasing, there is a forward emf, which can be interprested as additional voltage source.
Interpreting back emf and forward emf as voltages, we denote them by V_L. The relation of V_L with current I is not as simple as Ohm's law for resistance.
V_L = L \dfrac{dI}{dt}.
For an AC current with I(t) = I_0\, \cos(\omega t + \phi_I), we will get
V_L(t) = - \omega L I_0 \sin(\omega t + \phi_I).
We need to express V_L as cosine since we want to compare its phase to that of current I, which we are writing in cosine. When we change from sine to cosine, we will want to absorb the sign also. Therefore, V_L is
V_L(t) = \omega L I_0 \cos(\omega t + \phi_I + \frac{\pi}{2} ).
If we write V_L(t) in terms of its own magnitude and phase constant, i.e.,
V_L(t) =V_{L0} \cos(\omega t + \phi_V),
then, we find that current through an inductor and voltage across the inductor are not in-phase, but voltage is \dfrac{\pi}{2} radians or 90^\circ is ahead of the current.
\phi_V = \phi_I + \dfrac{\pi}{2},\ \ \ V_{L0} = \omega L I_0.
From the amplitude relation V_{L0} = \omega L I_0 , we see that inductor provides a frequency-dependent resistance. We call this resistance by another name, inductive reactance and denote it by X_L.
X_L = \omega L.
The phase relation in Eq. shows that, across an inductor, \phi_V \gt \phi_I. We say that, across an inductor, voltage leads current.
(Calculus) Voltage Drop Across a Capacitor
Suppose current I is flowing in a capacitor of capacitance C, and same amout of current is leaving the other plate. This means, charge q on plates is increasing.
Suppose q=0 at t=0, then, charge at instant t will be
q(t) = \int_0^t I(t) dt.
Voltage across a capacitor, denoted by V_C, will be given by the capacitor equation.
V_C = \dfrac{1}{C}\, q.
Therefore, we will have
V_C = \dfrac{1}{C}\, \int_0^t I(t) dt
For an AC current with I(t) = I_0\, \cos(\omega t + \phi_I), we will get
V_C(t) = \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\, I_0 \sin(\omega t + \phi_I).
We need to express V_C as cosine since we want to compare its phase to that of current I, which we are writing in cosine. Therefore, V_C is
V_C(t) = \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\, I_0 \cos(\omega t + \phi_I - \frac{\pi}{2} ).
If we write V_C(t) in terms of its own magnitude and phase constant, i.e.,
V_C(t) = V_{C0} \cos(\omega t + \phi_V),
then, we find that current into a capacitor and voltage across the capacitor are not in-phase, but voltage is \dfrac{\pi}{2} radians or 90^\circ is behind the current.
\phi_V = \phi_I - \dfrac{\pi}{2},\ \ \ V_{C0} = \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\, I_0.
From the amplitude relation V_{C0} = \dfrac{1}{\omega C}\, I_0 , we see that capacitor provides a frequency-dependent resistance. We call this resistance by another name, capacitative reactance and denote it by X_C.
X_C = \dfrac{1}{\omega C}.
The phase relation in Eq. shows that, across a capacitor, \phi_C \lt \phi_I. We say that, across a capcacitor, current leads voltage.
